questions.question_text: What information is flushed when the chunk-size value is changed in the config dlp settings?

choices.A: A unique value used to verify the input data
choices.D: An encrypted output value used to safe-guard the input data
choices.C: An obfuscation used to mask the input data.
choices.B: An output value that is used to identify the person or deduce that authored the input data.

questions.question_text: Which is the correct description of a hash result as it relates to digital certificates?

discussion.content:
A. Page 318 of the Security Study guide, "FortiGate compares the fresh hash result to the original hash result", compare as verify
B. Hash function/algorithm is irreversible, so it's not used to deduce the input data
C. Hashing is for comparison, not for encryption or security
D. Again, hashing is for comparison, not for encryption or security, it can be cracked with table lookup brute force
 
So the answer is A.
I think answer is A
Answer is A

think its B
https://security.stackexchange.com/questions/67512/what-role-do-hashes-play-in-tls-ssl-certificate-validation
I think it is A because the encrypted output value is not the hash result. The encrypted output value is the digital signature.

question says: as it relates to digital certificates
Page 318 of the Security Study guide says:
"The Hash result is refered to as the original hash result. CA encrypts the original hash with private key. The encrypted result is the digital certificate.
So I think answer is D (An encrypted output value)
I think it's A, but the answer is poorly worded. Page 318 of the Security study guide pdf, or slide#7 of Certificate Operations.
i think is B

It says:
"On the GUI, upload options include Real Time, Every Minute, and Every 5 Minutes (Default).

If your FortiGate model includes an internal hard drive, you also have the store-and-upload option. You can configure the store-and-upload option, as well as a schedule, on the CLI only. "
